title: The young Australian on the fintech frontline in Europe
text:
Daria Rippingale was 26 when she became a chief executive, and in a complex industry at that. Seven years ago, she was promoted to boss of BillPro, a risk management and compliance platform for the payments industry.

Daria Rippingale, co-founder and CEO of Bankingblocks. Supplied

Now 33, Rippingale is the major shareholder, co-founder and CEO of Bankingblocks, which is operating on the frontline of fintech in Europe. The company provides fintechs and payment companies with wholesale banking services, including managing compliance. It also helps incumbent banks connect to fintechs to improve customers’ experience.

Rippingale has been recognised for her leadership in this year’s Advance Awards, which highlight the achievements of Australia’s global diaspora. She won the gong for financial services, one of 10 category winners, after Advance received more than 200 nominations from 28 countries.

When BillPro decided not to expand into the European market four years ago, Rippingale made the move to the Netherlands to pursue the expansion herself. With the appearance of neobanks such as Starling, Monzo, Monese and Revolut in Britain, N26 in Germany and Qonto in France, she sensed an opportunity.

Bankingblocks’ model recognises that some of these start-ups – and there are dozens across Europe – have been set up by techies who aren’t on top of regulators’ demands and the rigours of compliance. Some have been struggling to get licences in multiple countries, which would allow them to start lending at scale.
description: Bankingblocks founder Daria Rippingale has been recognised by Advance Awards for achievement in financial services.
